title-group.article-title: Pressure pulse response of composite sandwich panels with plastic core damping

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH, USA

author-notes.corresp: Michelle S Hoo Fatt, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325, USA Email: hoofatt@uakron.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An analytical technique is presented for obtaining the large amplitude, damped response of a foam-core composite sandwich panel subjected to uniform pressure pulse loading. The predicted panel response was in agreement with finite element analysis, and it was used to examine the blast resistance of panels with various foam cores. Although blast resistance generally increased with the increasing core density, panels with the densest cores exhibited no energy absorption before panel failure. The panel with the PVC H200 foam also sustained higher failure pressure per unit areal weight density than the denser panels with Klegecell R300 and HCP100 foams.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lightweight composite sandwich panels with foam core not only offer high bending stiffness and strength per unit weight but they can dissipate energy when subjected to shock and impact. The cellular microstructure of the foam allows it to attenuate forces and absorb energy as it crushes at almost constant flow stress. Much of the literature concerning the dynamic response of composite sandwich panels under shock does not address the plastic deformation and energy absorption that take place in the sandwich core. Comprehensive reviews on this topic are given in References [1–4]. In composite sandwich plate theory, the core is treated as an elastic material rather than a crushable elastic–plastic material. It is assumed that the core transmits transverse shear forces, while the facesheets carry the bending moments across the panel. Shear deformations of the core are incorporated in sandwich plate theory, but the local indentation or crushing of the core within the panel is not accounted for in traditional sandwich plate theory. Significant emphasis has been placed instead on the development of higher order shear deformation theories to account for shear deformations of the core.

Hohe and Librescu [5] distinguish between single-layer and multi-layer approaches in sandwich panel theory. In the single-layer approach, one displacement function at the sandwich mid-plane is used to describe deformation of the entire sandwich, while in the multi-layer approach, three displacement functions for the two facesheets and core are assumed instead. The multi-layer approach can therefore be used to address core compressibility if deflections or out-of-plane displacements are different for the two facesheets. Recent attempts to incorporate core compressibility into the global response of composite sandwich plates and shells under blast are found in References [6–10]. Even in these studies, however, the sandwich core is treated as a linear elastic material rather than an elastic–plastic material.

Issues such as shock attenuation and energy absorption by the foam have not been taken into account in composite sandwich panels except for very recent work by Hoo Fatt et al.[11] This is in contrast to research on metallic sandwich panels with facesheets made of isotropic, ductile materials (metals) and metallic foams [12–15]. Energy absorption and blast mitigation of these structures are tantamount to plastic deformation in the core as well as the facesheets. Aluminum or steel facesheets in a metallic sandwich panel are ductile and break at 14%–25% strain, while glass or carbon fiber-reinforced polymer facesheets in a composite sandwich panel are elastic and break at 2%–4% strain. There is a great deal of plastic work dissipation in the facesheets of a metallic sandwich panel and no plastic work dissipation in the facesheets of a composite sandwich panel. Almost all the blast energy is absorbed by the time the facesheets reach maximum indentation in a metallic sandwich panel, while the energy is dissipated over many deformation cycles during vibratory response of a composite sandwich panel with elastic facesheets.

This paper covers the elastic and plastic response of a composite sandwich panel with woven E-Glass/Vinyl Ester facesheets and a Divinycell PVC H100 foam core during pressure pulse loading. An analytical model is presented for obtaining the large amplitude, damped response of the composite sandwich panel subjected to pressure pulse loading. The previous solution developed by Wu and Vinson [16] on the nonlinear oscillations of plates composed of composite materials is extended and modified to obtain the equations of motion for the composite sandwich panel. Plastic core damping is introduced as resistive forces in the equations of motion. Failure modes for the sandwich involving facesheet and core fracture are also considered. The analytical solution obtained is used to perform parametric studies on the blast resistance and energy absorption of the panel with different foam cores, including Divinycell PVC H30, H100, H200 and HCP100, and Klegecell R300 foams. Finite element analysis (FEA) using ABAQUS Explicit is done to simulate the blast load response of flat sandwich panel and the FEA results are used to corroborate the analytical solutions.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p:
The problem considered is the simply-supported, composite sandwich panel shown in Figure 1 subjected to uniformly distributed pressure pulse given by (1) where p0 is the peak pressure, ΔT is the load duration and t is time. The sandwich panel is symmetric with orthotropic facesheets that are linear elastic. The foam core of the sandwich panel is idealized as isotropic, elastic, perfectly plastic material. The elastic, perfectly plastic material assumption for the core is based on the core crushing material test data for PVC H100 foam shown in Figure 2(a). The corresponding elastic, perfectly plastic material idealization for the foam is shown in Figure 2(b). Here, the compressive strains are small but large enough to cause foam plasticity. In cellular material, strain hardening and foam densification will occur at higher compressive strains [17]. The foam strains in the composite sandwich panel are not as large as in a metallic sandwich panel because the composite facesheet ductility is only a few percent and this limits the relative crushing of the foam between facesheets. In metallic sandwich panels, facesheets are ductile and the core may undergo substantial crushing before facesheet rupture. Another reason for assuming small strains in the foam is due to the fact that many polymer foams would break at larger strains in uniaxial tension and shear modes. In addition to the perfectly plastic material idealization, the foam is understood as being isotropic. The PVC H100 foam is actually transversely isotropic and plastic yielding, due to cellular wall buckling, and occurs in compression and shear but not in tension. There is no anisotropic crushable foam model available to date. The present state-of-the art in modeling crushable foam is to obtain the through-thickness compressive stress–strain properties of the foam and assume it as an isotropic material with these properties. An elastic, perfectly plastic isotropic foam is thus assumed in this paper. Figure 1.
Composite sandwich panel. Figure 2.
Compressive stress–strain curve for PVC H100: (a) actual test results at 0.1 s−1 strain rate and (b) elastic perfectly plastic material.

The large amplitude, forced response of the sandwich panel is a modification of the free vibration solution of a simply-supported, composite sandwich panel given by Wu and Vinson [16]. In Reference 16, a single-layer approach is used to describe the free vibration response of a composite sandwich panel using first-order shear deformation theory for the sandwich configuration and taking finite membrane strains into account. Both the facesheets and core of the sandwich panel are assumed to be linear elastic. The sandwich panel bending, membrane and transverse shear resistance are calculated from the combined facesheet and core properties as well as the geometry and layup of the panel. This sandwich panel theory is a classic, first-order approximation of the dynamic response of a simply-supported, composite sandwich panel [18]. Two modifications are made to this basic sandwich panel theory: (1) forced instead of free vibrations are considered and (2) plastic damping resistance functions are introduced during plastic yielding of the core.

The Euler-Lagrangian equations of motions for the sandwich panel were derived using Reissner’s Variational Method and Hamilton’s Principle and they are written as (2) (3) (4) where α¯,β¯ are rotations associated with x- and y-axes, w is the panel deflection, Mij and Qij are the bending moment and transverse shear force resultants, γ2=A22/A11, A22 and A11 are in-plane membrane stiffness, M¯ is the equivalent mass and I¯ is equivalent rotary inertia, and I¯e is the first invariant of the mid-plane strains of the composite sandwich plate. The sandwich plate equivalent mass and rotary inertia are (5) (6) where ρk is the density of the kth ply and n is the total number of plies. Following Reference 16, I¯e for a simply-supported plate is (7)

It is assumed that facesheets carry bending moment resistance, while the core resists transverse shear forces. Since the facesheets are linear elastic, the bending moments in an orthotropic elastic, symmetric sandwich panel, the bending moments are (8) where Dij is the bending stiffness of the panel. Energy dissipation or absorption is due to plastic yielding of the core, which for a simply-supported panel is driven primarily by high transverse shear stresses at the panel edges. The transverse shear resultant forces may be elastic or elastic–plastic as described in the following section.

sec.title: Transient response of sandwich plate
sec.p: The transient response of the sandwich panel is found by satisfying the equations of motion specified in Equations (2) to (4). For simply-supported boundary conditions, the deformations are assumed to be of the form (9) (10) (11) where W11, Γ11 and Λ11 are time-varying amplitudes of the transverse deflection and shear rotations. The above equations represent a one-term Fourier series approximation.

sec.title: Forced elastic response
sec.p: If the core remains elastic during panel deformation, the transverse shear resultants are (12) where A44,A55 are transverse shear stiffness of the panel. Substituting Equations (8) and (12) into Equations (2) to (4) give the equations of motion governing plate deformations as (13) (14) (15) where Δ2 is a coupling parameter defined by (16)
Substituting Equations (9) to (11) into Equations (13) to (15) gives (17) (18) (19) where p¯11=16p(t)/π2 and p(t) is defined in Equation (1).

sec.title: Forced elastic–plastic response
sec.p:
Following an elastic, perfectly plastic isotropic material idealization for the foam core, the foam may undergo several loading and unloading cycles as depicted in Figure 3. Plastic regions develop in the core and plastic work is dissipated every time there is core yielding. The following sections describe equations of motion for initial core yielding during the first loading cycle, followed by subsequent unloading and reverse core yielding. Conditions for plastic yielding during continued loading and unloading cycles or vibrations are then explained after this. Since plastic work is dissipative, the panel will eventually run out of enough energy to induce further plasticity. At this point, the sandwich panel will undergo purely elastic vibrations. Figure 3.
Compressive stress–strain curve during initial yielding, elastic unloading and reverse yielding.

sec.title: A. Initial plastic yielding
sec.p: Following Equations (10) and (11), the transverse shear strains are given by (20) (21) where γ13=W11π/a+Γ11 and γ23=W11π/b+Λ11. The transverse shear strains are therefore maximum at the panel edges, that is, γxz is maximum at x=0,a and γyz is maximum at y=0,b.

Plastic yielding of the core takes place when the transverse shear strains near the simply-supported edges exceed the transverse shear yield strains. The conditions for shear yielding is given in Appendix 1, where perfect plasticity was assumed. Although the analysis is limited to cores that undergo crushing at constant flow stress, foam hardening, could be accounted for in the perfectly-plastic assumption by increasing the yield or flow stress.

Four plastic regions (approximately half ellipses) will develop along the sides of the plate as shown in Figure 4. To evaluate the minor and major axes of the plastic ellipses, the transverse shear strains are set equal to the transverse shear yield strains: (22) (23) where γ130=τ0/G13 and γ230=τ0/G23 are the transverse shear strain at yield, as defined in Figures 3(a) and (b). Figure 4.
Plastic dissipation regions in the core of the sandwich plate.

The transverse shear resultants (Qx,Qy) for the forced elastic–plastic response of the sandwich are given as (24) (25) where Qx0 and Qy0 are the transverse shear resultant forces at yield. From Appendix 1, one finds that during yielding (26) (27)
Substituting these expressions into Equations (2) to (4) give the following differential equations in the plastic region (S2): (28) (29) (30)

In the elastic region (S1) shown in Figure 4, the differential equations of motion are specified by equations (13) to (15). The combined elastic–plastic equations of motion are found by integrating these differential equations with weighting functions over the surface area of the panel. This is done in Appendix 2, and the resulting equations of motion for elastic–plastic response are as follows: (31) where
and
(32) where

(33) where
and
Resistive damping forces Qdx,Qdy and pd are recognized in the above equations of motion governing elastic–plastic response.

sec.title: B. Elastic unloading
sec.p:
Eventually the panel reaches a peak displacement and begins to rebound. This rebound leads to elastic unloading in the plastic regions, as depicted in Figure 5. The transverse shear force resultants are given by (34) (35) where
and
are the distributed maximum transverse shear strain before unloading. The maximum values of the transverse shear strains at the first unloading, γ13m (1) and γ23m (1), are defined in Figures 6(a) and (b). Substituting these expressions into Equations (2) to (4) and solving the weighted integrals as defined earlier give (36) (37) (38) where Qdx (1),Qdy (1),pd (1),f1 (1),f2 (1) and f3 (1) are the respective values at the start of unloading. Figure 5.
New plastic regions in core during reverse yielding. Figure 6.
Transverse shear force resultants during initial yielding and elastic unloading: (a) Qxversus γxz and (b) Qy versus γyz.

sec.title: C. Reverse yielding
sec.p:
The panel could have enough residual energy during the rebound to cause reverse yielding in the core. When this happens, another plastic region (S3) will emerge within the previous region (S2), which is unloading (see Figure 5). The transverse shear force resultants in S3 are shown in Figures 7(a) and (b). The size of this new plastic zone is given by (39) (40) Figure 7.
Transverse shear force resultants during reverse yield: (a) Qx versus γxz and (b) Qy versus γyz.
The transverse shear force resultants in the core are now described by (41) (42)
Substituting these expressions into Equations (2) to (4) and integrating with weighted functions give (43) (44) (45)

sec.title: D. Consecutive unloading/yielding
sec.p:
The first reverse yielding may be followed by several cycles of unloading and yielding. The transverse shear force resultants shown in Figures 8(a) and (b) indicate that each cycle ends with maximum transverse shear strain γ13m (k) or γ23m (k), where k=3. Each time the core yields a new plastic zone develops, smaller than the previous one. In general, the plastic zone size is given by (46) (47) where sgn(γ·13) and sgn(γ·23) are negative for unloading and positive for reloading. Figure 8.
Transverse shear force resultants during consecutive yielding/unloading and yielding/reloading: (a) Qx versus γxz and (b) Qy versus γyz.
During unloading/reloading, the transverse shear force resultants are (48) (49)

The equations of motion during unloading/reloading are (50) (51) (52) where Qdx (k-1),Qdy (k-1),pd (k-1),f1 (k-1),f2 (k-1) and f3 (k-1) are the respective values at the start of unloading or reloading.
During yielding, the transverse shear force resultants are (53) (54)
The equations of motion during yielding are (55) (56) (57)

sec.title: FEA
sec.p:
A simply-supported rectangular composite sandwich panel of length a = 740 mm, breadth b = 740 mm, facesheet thickness h = 6 mm and core thickness H = 25 mm was considered. The facesheet was E-Glass/Vinyl Ester, while the core was Divinycell PVC H100. The material properties of the facesheet and core are given in Table 1. Orthotropic elastic properties were specified for the facesheet. For purely elastic behavior, the core was specified and an isotropic, linear elastic material with the through-thickness compression elastic properties of the foam listed in Table 1. For elastic–plastic behavior, the core was specified as crushable foam with isotropic hardening. [19] The plasticity curve for Divinycell PVC H100 foam was taken from Mines and Alias [20] and the plastic Poisson’s ratio was taken to be zero. Table 1.
Material properties of 0/90 woven roving E-Glass/Vinyl Ester and different foams

E11 (−) (GPa) 19 0.027 0.105 0.293 0.338 0.340
E22 (−) (GPa) 19 0.027 0.105 0.293 0.338 0.340
E33 (−) (GPa) – 0.027 0.105 0.293 0.338 0.340

ν13 = ν23 0.28 0.25 0.31 0.3 0.23 0.3
ν31 = ν32 0.12 0.25 0.31 0.3 0.23 0.3

G23 = G32 (GPa) 1.73 0.013 0.0438 0.110 0.123 0.131
G13 = G31 (GPa) 1.73 0.013 0.0438 0.110 0.123 0.131
q (MPa) – 0.3 1.66 4.35 7.8 10.3
εD – 0.85 0.8 0.7 0.285 0.15
XT, σ10 (+) (MPa) 270 0.57 3.2 6.4 – –
XC, σ10 (−) (MPa) 200 0.29 1.53 4.36 – –
YT, σ20 (+) (MPa) 270 0.57 3.5 6.4 – –
YC, σ20 (−) (MPa) 200 0.29 1.53 4.36 – –
SL, τ120 = τ210 (MPa) 40 0.35 1.47 3.86 – 7.44
ST,τ13f = τ310 (MPa) 31.6 0.35 1.47 3.86 – 7.44
ST,τ230 = τ320 (MPa) 31.6 0.35 1.47 3.86 – 7.44

Due to the symmetry of the problem, only a quarter section of the composite sandwich panel was modeled in ABAQUS, as shown in Figure 9(a). To simulate pinned boundary conditions, frictionless, rigid rollers were placed along the edges of the panel. A small overhang was allowed beyond the rollers to prevent slippage. The mesh of the quarter section is shown in Figure 9(b). The facesheets were rigidly tied to the core. Eight-node linear brick elements (C3D8) were used for both the facesheet and the core. A very fine mesh, with a total of 627,360 elements, was used in this FEA. More details of the FEA can be found in Reference 21.

The composite sandwich panel was subjected to a uniformly distributed pressure pulse load of magnitude p0= 0.25 MPa and load duration of ΔT= 4 ms, with the time history described in Equation (1). Dynamic, Explicit analysis with nonlinear geometry was performed in the FEA. A comparison of FEA and analytical results was done assuming the core was purely elastic and elastic–plastic.

sec.title: Purely elastic response
sec.p:
The panel center deflection and shear strain at the edges during purely elastic response are given in Figures 10,(a) and (b), respectively. Here the core had no plastic dissipation and the sandwich panel behaved as fully elastic. Solutions from the coupled equations of motion defined in Equations (17) to (19), using ode45 solver in MATLAB, are also shown in Figures 10(a) and (b) for comparison. The predicted results for the panel center deflection and the shear strains at the edges are in remarkable good agreement with the FEA results, given that only a one-term approximation was taken for the deflection and rotations. This is especially true up to the first peak but the two solutions deviated somewhat at longer times. The deviation at late time is not surprising because explicit time integration algorithms in ABAQUS Explicit and MATLAB incorporate numerical damping to keep them stable. Numerical damping will result in small errors that are generally insignificant during transient analysis, such as the panel response during the application of the pressure pulse. However, these errors can accumulate over long periods of time. Other numerical schemes should be employed for purely vibration analysis. Figure 9.
FEA model of simply-supported, sandwich panel: (a) quarter model and (b) mesh. FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Elastic–plastic response
sec.p:
The FEA shows that plasticity in the core occurs first near the panel edges where the transverse shear strains are high, as predicted by the analytical model. The transverse shear strains peak out near the roller support and not directly at the support. Recall that the roller supports on the facesheets (see Figure 9(a)) were used to simulate simply-supported boundary conditions. The shape of the plastic region from FEA is also a similar, although not exactly the same, to the one described in the analytical model as the plastic zone spreads. Figures 11(a) and (b) shows the distribution of plastic transverse shear strain at 2.48 ms, which corresponds to the time when the transverse shear strains reach the first maximum and the plastic zone is the most extensive. The facesheets are removed in Figures 11(a) and (b) so that lines of constant plastic transverse shear strains in the foam core are visible. The elastic region is defined where plastic strains are zero. Plastic regions, resembling the assumed semi-elliptical shapes in the analytical model, can be seen emanating from the panel edges along x- and y-boundaries. These plastic regions coalesce on the diagonal axis when the two transverse plastic shear strains overlap. The overlap regions also occur in the analytical model, and they are taken into consideration in the proposed elastic–plastic integration functions. Figure 10.
Comparison of fully elastic solutions and FEA results: (a) deflection at panel center and (b) transverse shear strain edge, x ¼ a: FEA: finite element analysis. Figure 11.
FEA model showing the plastic region: (a) plastic γ13 and (b) plastic γ23. FEA: finite element analysis.

The FEA and analytical comparisons for the panel center deflection and transverse shear strains are given in Figures 12(a) and (b). The predicted and FEA results are in relatively good agreement up to the first peak. The predicted peak displacement and transverse shear strain are about 15% and 11% higher than FEA results, respectively. The main reason for the difference in solutions is the approximation of plastic regions as semi-ellipses in the analytical model. Such an approximation was appropriate with a one-term Fourier series approximation for the transverse deflection and shear rotations, but this approximation may not be as accurate in predicting the spatial distribution transverse shear strain in the core. More terms of the Fourier series would be needed to more accurately define the plastic region and resulting, elastic–plastic integration functions. In addition to this, the predicted and FEA solutions deviate at later times as was the case in the purely elastic response. Again the discrepancy at later times is attributed to accumulated numerical errors in the individual explicit solvers. Figure 12.
Comparison of elastic–plastic solutions and FEA results: (a) deflection at panel center and (b) transverse shear strain edge, x = a. FEA: finite element analysis.

To elucidate the effect of core plasticity, the predicted sandwich panel response during purely elastic and elastic–plastic core behaviors are compared in Figures 13(a) and (b). During elastic response, the panel vibrates about a zero mean equilibrium position after the load duration of 4 ms. During elastic–plastic response, the panel oscillates about a permanent deflection and with permanent transverse shear strains at the edges after the load duration. The amplitude of vibrations is smaller after the first unloading in the elastic–plastic panel because of energy dissipation due to plasticity. This same trend also occurs in the FEA. Figure 13.
Comparison of purely elastic and elastic–plastic response: (a) deflection at panel center and (b) transverse shear strain edge, x = a.

sec.title: Sandwich panel failure
sec.p: Analytical models provide simple design tools for determining the survivability of the panel when it is subjected to an intense pressure pulse load. The facture of the woven E-Glass/Vinyl Ester facesheet and PVC foam core are examined in this section.

sec.title: Facesheet fracture
sec.p: The facesheet failure may be either compressive or tensile failure in the top or bottom facesheet. The failure of the facesheet is predicted using a modified Hashin-Rotem failure criterion for the woven composites [22]. For an orthotropic ply, (58) (59) (60) where the in-plane strains are (61) (62) (63)
To evaluate these strains, a one-term approximation for the in-plane deformations is assumed as (64) (65)

In a square sandwich plate, σx and σy are equal since b = a. The normal stresses σx and σy are also greater than the in-plane shear stress of the facesheet. Substituting Equations (64) and (65) into Equation (61) yields (66)
Based on the assumption ∂I¯e∂x=∂I¯e∂y=0, [16] one gets: (67)

For the simply-supported panel, the principal stress components in the facesheets (σx or σy) are greatest at the center of the panel (x=a/2,y=a/2) at z=±(H/2+h). Based on the material properties for the E-Glasss/Vinyl Ester given in Table 1, it was found that the bottom facesheet failed in tension. The criterion for the bottom facesheet fracture is (68) where XT is the tensile strength of the facesheet.

sec.title: Core failure
sec.p: The core failure is due to transverse shear fracture at the edge. The core shear failure criteria are (69) (70) where γ13f and γ23f are transverse shear fracture strains.

sec.title: Effect of core properties
sec.p:
A parametric study was done to determine the effect of core properties on the panel blast resistance using the above failure criteria. Square panels (a=b=1.48m,h=6mm and H=25mm) with several cores, Divinycell PVC H30, H100, H200 and HCP100 and Klegecell R300 were considered. The load duration was kept at 4 ms and the peak pressure to panel failure was examined. Facesheet failure was due to tensile fracture of the bottom facesheet and core failure occurred when the transverse shear strain at panel edges reaches the transverse shear fracture strain. The transverse shear yield strain (γ130) and fracture strain (γ13f) for the different foams are as shown in Table 2. Transverse shear fracture strains were only found for the PVC H30 foam [23] and H100 foam [24]. According to References 25 and 26, the critical shear strain for failure increases with increase in the density of the core. It was assumed that the transverse shear fracture strain for the PVC H200 was greater than that for the PVC H100 [24], and the transverse shear fracture strain for the Klegecell R300 and Divinycell HCP100 were taken to be greater than their respective yield strains. Table 2.
Transverse shear strain at yield and fracture
H30 H100 H200 R300 HCP100
γ130,γ230 0.016 0.029 0.028 0.045 0.056
γ13f,γ23f 0.09 0.16 >0.16 >0.045 >0.056

Figure 14(a) shows the failure pressure at failure with different foam core materials. The blast resistance of the panel increases with increasing foam core density, and it can be seen that the panel with HCP100 foam as a core material is the most blast resistant. It was found that the panels with lower core densities (H30 and H100) failed due to core shear failure while the panels with highest core densities (H200, R300 and HCP100) failed due to facesheet fracture. The panels with the highest core densities (R300 and HCP100) did not even yield (no plasticity) before facesheet fracture. These panels behaved elastically up to failure. The H200 foam panel just yielded before there was facesheet failure. The dissipation energy in the panels that exhibited plasticity up to the point of failure is approximately given by (71) Figure 14.
Effect of different foam cores on (a) failure pressure and (b) energy absorbed to failure.
The corresponding energy absorption for the panels before failure are shown in Figure 14(b).

The failure pressure was normalized by the areal weight density ρw of the panel. The areal weight density is given by (72) where ρc and ρf are the core and facesheet density, respectively, and g is the acceleration due to gravity. The blast resistance of the panel with H200 foam core has the highest failure pressure per unit areal weight density as shown in Figure 15. Figure 15.
Failure pressure per areal weight density in sandwich panels with various cores.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An analytical model for the damped, large amplitude response of a simply-supported sandwich panel with E-Glass/Vinyl Ester facing and PVC foam core under pressure pulse loading has been presented. The composite facesheets and the crushable PVC foam core were considered to be orthotropic elastic and isotropic elastic–plastic material, respectively. Plastic core damping was introduced as resistive forces in the Euler-Lagrangian equations of motion for the plate undergoing large amplitude, forced vibrations. FEA was also done using ABAQUS Explicit to gage the accuracy of the analytical solution. The predicted results for the panel center deflection and the shear strains at the edges compared well with the FEA results. Failure of the sandwich panel was either due to the rupture of the bottom facesheet at the center of the panel or due to the transverse shear fracture of the foam core at the edges of the panel.

A parametric study using the analytical model was done to determine the effect of foam core materials. Five core materials namely, Divinycell PVC H30, H100, H200 and HCP100, and Klegecell R300 foams were used in the study. Foam density played a major role in determining the panel mode of failure. The sandwich panel with low-density H30 and H100 foam cores failed due to core shear fracture, while the panels with higher density H200, R300 and HCP 100 foams failed due to tensile rupture of the facesheet. The blast resistance of the sandwich panel increased with increasing core density, but when compared on a per unit areal weight density, the panel with the H200 foam core was found to be more blast resistant than panels with the denser Klegecell R300 and Divinycell HCP100 foams. Furthermore, foam cores with lighter densities absorbed more energy compared to those with higher densities. The sandwich panels with the highest densities, R300 and HCP100, exhibited no plasticity or energy absorption before failure.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge financial support from Dr Yapa Rajapakse at the Office of Naval Research under Grant N00014-11-1-0485.

sec.title: Shear yielding
sec.p: For the shear yielding of the foam core the yield surface according to Deshpande and Fleck [27] is given by (A1) where σ0, σe, σm and μ are the foam yield strength, the misses effective stress, mean stress and the flow potential, respectively, where (A2) (A3) (A4) and νp is the plastic Poisson’s ratio. The stresses in the foam are primarily transverse shear (A5)
Substituting Equation (A5) into Equations (A2) and (A3) gives (A6)
During plasticity, the plastic Poisson’s ratio is approximately zero. Therefore, Equation (A4) becomes (A7)
Substituting Equations (A6) and (A7) into Equation (A1) yields (A8)
Equation (A8) can be written as (A9) where τ0=σ0/2. In terms of transverse shear resultant forces (A10) where Q0=τ0H.
In general, Qx0and Qy0 vary with x and y At the point of yielding, the transverse shear force resultants are related to transverse shear strains and (A11) (A12)
Therefore, (A13) (A14)
Substituting equations (A13) and (A14) into equation (A10) gives (A15) (A16)

sec.title: Elastic–plastic integration functions
sec.p: In the elastic region (shown S1 as in Figure 4), the differential equations of motion are specified by Equations (13) to (15), while in the plastic region (shown as S2 in Figure 4), the equations of motion are specified by Equations (28) and (30). The combined elastic–plastic equations of motion are found by integrating these differential equations with weighting functions over the surface area of the panel. The choice of the weighting function stems from Hamilton’s Principle, which in Reference 16 was used to derive the Euler-Lagrangian equations of motion. Since Equations (2) to (4) are associated with variations in α¯,β¯ and w, respectively, the weighting functions are the spatial variations for them in Equations (9) to (11).

Equations (28) and (13) are pre-multiplied by cos(πxa)sin(πyb) before integration over the entire plate surface area: (B1) where
and

Equations (29) and (14) are pre-multiplied by sin(πxa)cos(πyb) before integration over the plate surface area: (B2) where
and

Equations (20) and (15) are pre-multiplied by sin(πxa)sin(πyb) before integration over the plate surface area: (B3) where
and
Resistive damping forces Qdx,Qdy and pd are recognized in the above equations of motion governing elastic–plastic response.

For a square sandwich panel b = a, ζ′0 = η′0 = ζ0 = η0, f1 = f2 and Qdx=Qdy. The integral functions, f1,f3,Qdx and pd are evaluated by Chapagain [21] and summarized below:
and
where η¯0=2η0a is a normalized plastic region. The above integration was performed numerically and is only valid when 0<η¯0<1.
